Yep! It smells a little. Here are possible=
 refactorings.

1. The constructor opens the file so that "write" and "clos=
e" operations
always "make sense" on any instantiation of that class. If op=
en() fails,
then there's no object on which to erroneously call write() and=
 close().
2. The open() operation is a factory method for another object th=
at wraps
the file. You write/close by talking to the file. Come to think of=
 it, this
is the same as 1.

The only problem with assertions in code is th=
at people find it easy to
abuse them. If every developer were disciplined e=
nough to use in-code
assertions only when no other way works, then they wou=
ldn't be such a
